page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY - SULLINGTON
page.content: Sullington was first called Syling-tun, meaning farmstead by miry place. About thirty different spellings followed including Semlintun, Shylington, Sylyngton, Solington and Sullingg. Several groups of Bronze Age tumuli are in this area. Years ago two were opened and inside each was a sepulchral urn of unbaked clay containing burnt bones. Both urns had different designs and a small bronze awl was found. Over the years hundreds of arrow shaped heads of early weapons, plus Roman swords and spearheads have also been found. Earthwork remains of a Roman Hill Camp and a field system of terraces can be clearly seen. Several cross dykes on the higher part of the Downs were used for driving the Southdown sheep to market.
